I loved this puzzle.  Only one crunchy spot for me (Sec of War Root). Otherwise it was fun to work out the puns which, if I‚Äôm to be completely frank, I normally despise but genuinely enjoyed these.

A problem with 33D. Llama does not start with 2 ELS but rather with the single digraph ‚Äúll‚Äù. See any Spanish dictionary. Yes, I know that we are in the world of xwordese with some permissible laxity.

Hi all,

The link from the puzzle page to the Wednesday column has now been fixed. Please refresh the puzzle page and click away to your heart's content.

Being a connoisseur of history WWIIVET was a gimme. Enjoyed 17a QUITE A BIT. For some reason unknown to a lover of CRAFT BEERS it took me a while to figure it out. Also enjoyed M(lies) P(er) G(allon) crossing the gas in Amigas and model plane. A bit of irony there. Very well crafted puzzle.

Great puzzle! And really great constructors' notes. I did this puzzle while having a screwdriver and boy did I get hammered!

Don't know if anyone has mentioned this, but Nick Offerman is also a master carpenter, and that crack of his about making a Greene & Greene inspired thingy for your Craftsman bungalow wasn't just him blowing wind up your pantaloons, he actually can! And does! He's even said that all that acting and film stuff gets in the way of his being a carpenter. Dude!

Great, now I have yet another reason to be a fan of Offerman's. Two, really, since we're both vintage 1970.

Great fun puzzle with quite a few chewy bits in there - not a breeze by any stretch of the imagination, had to earn this one. 

Thanks, Nick and Christina!

Mesmerizing tool with which to measure twice before you cut once?

MAGNETIC TAPE

Love it when the puzzle is funny and the constructor‚Äôs notes even funnier!

Great collaboration!  A fun and punny puzzle that had me groaning  and laughing out loud.  Nick Offerman is a national treasure.  Nick for President!  His slogan can be ‚ÄúVote N.O. For Less Drama, More Comedy.‚Äù
ANTEGG crossing with GOB was my sticking point. Had  MOB And had never heard of Thai tidbits anywhere near the right letters.

In re: the mini, 1A is just plain wrong.

In computing if you are differentiating laptops, Macs run MacOS and PCs run Windows.

Chromebooks run neither, so the clue (‚ÄúChromebooks but not MacBooks‚Äù) is nonsensical.
Just posting to see  whether I can. My posts aren‚Äôt showing up.
Chewy for a Wednesday.  Good stuff.
Since the Eames couple were a team, only a clue of "Chairman or Chairwoman" would seem acceptable.

I saw the constructors names and immediately went to Xwordinfo to see if it was ‚Äúthat‚Äù Nick Offerman with our beloved Christina Iverson and lo and behold it was! Then of course I read Deb‚Äôs column upon completion and she confirmed my suspicions as well ü§ì I believe Parks and Recreation was the brainchild of the staff of our Parks and Rec department in El Segundo where I used to live and the real director at the time was Ron Swanson (Nick Offerman‚Äôs character namesake). One of my favorite shows. My husband is also a fan of Nick in The Last of Us. 
As for the puzzle, I‚Äôm seriously impressed. Is there nothing that Nick can‚Äôt do?! Cheers to Christina for taking him under her wing. This really made my day. ü§©

Thought the IBSEN SEDARIS cross would be my undoing, but the name SEDARIS floated into my head from who-knows-where. Couldn't even say for sure what their first name is. David, maybe? It's fun when you have those bolt from the blue moments.

The real issue turned out to be POKEY! Had to reveal that one.

Nice puzzle. 

Although THE TUBE and the London Underground are used interchangeably these days they are two different systems and use different trains. 

The Piccadilly line is part of the Tube and the Circle line the Underground.

It's only my opinion, but one-word clues are lazy and should be kept to a minimum. It's more satisfying to solve with logic than with learning a thesaurus by heart. 

But the theme was fun üòä
Well DRAFTBEERS and DPLUS made perfect sense to me‚Ä¶

"34A Noted chairman?"--EAMES???

I don't know, I'd say that one's a bit obscure.
ANT EGG may be a delicacy in Thai cuisine, but I'd certainly hope it's not "popular."

Congratulations to Mr Offerman on his debut. As an amateur constructor myself I know only too well the challenges he describes, and I recommend fellow solvers check out free tools like Crosshare or Phil and try their hand at some light construction themselves - the difficulty is at least an order of magnitude above that of simply solving and is a cerebral work-out like few others.

All my life I've spelled it "saviour".  

I had a mistake, and I couldn't find it because partly I was sure SAVIOR was missing a letter somehow.

I've been really walloped by the three "easy" puzzles this week so far.  Had a mistake in all of them.  Had a hard time finding the mistake in all of them. 

I wish I were Nick Offerman.

I had dPLUS and dRAFTBEER, both of which scanned fine. Took me a while to find them! 

Fun puzzle. I would admit that I've not ever seen Parks and Recreation, so the actor was unknown to me. I'll have a look at it, as it seems well like by this crowd.

Fun puzzle!  Loved the clues and the constructor‚Äôs notes.  So kudos to Nick Offerman and his Sherpa, Christina Iverson.  

Of course, Parks & Rec will remain a favorite of mine. Does anyone else remember his Nick, the plumber, character on a 2001 episode of Will & Grace?  He and Karen Walker (Megan Mullally, now is real life wife) played a hilarious scene.  Chemistry.

Average solve time on an above average Wednesday puzzle.

So much fun and a bit of a challenge for a Wednesday And here's an unlocked link to an article about Nick that was posted a few days ago. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/13/style/nick-offerman-woodwork.html?unlocked_article_code=1.tk8.QuIC.U7korArU8HPc&smid=url-share

An abbreviated version of David Sedaris's "Santaland Diaries" was a staple of NPR's "Morning Edition" every year around Christmas for at least a decade. (Just as Susan Stamberg's cranberry relish recipe was featured on "All Things Considered" every year around Thanksgiving). But the full 30-minute version of "Santaland Diaries" is worth hearing. It's by turns sardonic, witty, and moving (and definitely racier than the version played on NPR). Here's a link to the full version from the podcast "This American Life" back in 1996: - https://www.thisamericanlife.org/47/christmas-and-commerce/act-two-22

If it weren't for my 88 day streak, I would have thrown in the towel on this after about 15 minutes. Instead, I spent a solid 20 minutes on the last two squares (EA_E_), a double Natick. I was halfway through bruteforcing all 676 permutations before I remembered that it's IRA Glass, not Ari Glass and that Shapiro was the usual clue for ARI.

LORDJIM was the most obvious guess, so only needed max 26 guesses to finish. The S was probably 10th. I would have thought calling something GAS was a bad thing...

35 minutes

Good puzzle, and very nice collaboration. There were a few unfamiliar answers that I wasn't sure of and had to wait on crosses for confirmation, and any time a puzzle puts me in that situation I tend to enjoy it more than one where I can put everything in from the beginning.

Congrats on the debut! And thanks to both Nick and Christina!

Hard for a Wednesday (25% slower than average) but an enjoyable workout.  I noticed the famous co-constructor right off the bat and was curious what that would bring: a pretty fun and moderately difficult puzzle as it turns out.

What a delightful debut. And while I might cavil about ANTEGGs being popular (never had 'em), that would just be a bore. But I do have a major boen to pick about the mini: MacBooks are Personal Computers just as much as Chromebooks are. I beg rhe NYT xword team to stop buying into the Apple propaganda and take a stand for the equality of personal computing platforms.

It's been a while since I've done a Wednesday puzzle, so 4 mins overy average seemed like I must be rusty. Then I came here and saw I wasn't the only one who struggled a bit more with this Wednesday. Loved the theme, had a couple of Naticks, ultimately finished it. Thank you Nick and Christina for a great puzzle.

I've been at it for 23 minutes now - that's my usual Thursday/Friday time - and the grid is still 30-40% empty. I have to go to work in a few minutes. I wonder if I will be able to complete the grid, especially without lookups. Dotted with trivia, clued on a wavelength my brain just can't tune into, with a theme that still eludes me after getting one of its entries - it's proving more of a challenge than some Saturdays. I'll get back to y'all on my progress or lack thereof. For now here is Lucek the puppy on his longest walk yet, in Warsaw's Las Kabacki (Kabacki Forest; Kabaty is a place name, once a village, now a subdivision of the Ursyn√≥w district): https://imgur.com/a/LF8ZZwP

A well crafted puzzle, with the veneer of an heirloom, and the polish of a craftsman.  A puzzle built to weather complaints about the framing and open doors to new experiences, warm and entertaining, with old friends like Hank Ibsen, Dave Sedaris, Chuck Eames, Ira Glass, Joe Conrad (no need to bring up Jim and the unfortunate business about the S.S. Patma)‚Äîamigos galore (but I think just the one amiga). 

What I'm trying to say is that I enjoyed this puzzle quite a bit.  (Let's order up another crafty beer and toss back some turtles.)

Come back again, Nick.  Don't let this just be a one-off fling with Christina. She had a wonderful time too, and the door is always open for an encore.  You made a wonderful team.

Haven‚Äôt even started the puzzle- but I had to come to the column to confirm the co-constructor was indeed *that* Nick Offerman. Was already looking forward to this solve as it‚Äôll be my 2000th Times puzzle solved (not as a streak- that‚Äôs in the mid 600‚Äôs). Will come back post solve to see how I fared!

The theme was cute, and the revealer made me smile, but it bothers me that JIGGETY JIG doesn't really fit the pattern. Am I missing something? I mean, 'JIGGETY' isn't a superlative the way BOSS or MODEL or even QUITE A is.
AEGIS is also the name of the primary radar weapons system installed on U.S. Navy surface ships. It is of course named for the shield in Greek mythology.

‚Ä¶and the constructor‚Äôs notes‚Ä¶

My day can *only* go downhill from here.

I've never been frustrated while solving a NYT crossword and then not appreciated the puzzle in the end.  But, there's a first time for everything and this was it.  There was nothing redeeming about this one. It wasn't particularly clever, there were no times when I finally got a clue that perplexed me and it made me chuckle that it took me so long to get the hook, etc.  It was mildly disappointing.  At least I have coffee.
Which were the other puzzles by celebrity constructors?

A lively word-playing fun theme, a revealer that brings a ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù, the magnificent JIGGETY, its abutting splendid NERFED, another tool (AWL) in the box to echo the theme, and as icing, Nick‚Äôs fabulous frenetic notes ‚Äì what a GAS!

When the outing goes beyond being a satisfying fill-in and brings joy into the equation, when it jumps from being not only clever, but entertaining as well, it‚Äôs one of those moments where I‚Äôm not joining a standing-O because everyone else is doing it, rather, it‚Äôs one of those moments where I‚Äôm the first to rise and begin the standing-O.

Brava and bravo, Nick and Christina!  You took me from neutral to vroom, from chill to jiggety, and set me bounding into my day.  Thank you so much for this, and encore!

Wow. Way over my average, and the hardest Wednesday I can remember.

Every clue was clever (well, I've never heard of eating ANTEGGs), not too much obscure trivia, just generally enjoyable. 

Oh, and a mention of a Secretary of War back when we actually had a Secretary of War.

Thanks!

So busy fangirling about our co-constructer I forgot to mention one of the funniest things I‚Äôve ever read by David SEDARIS, from The Santaland Diaries. Here is a David reading it. Genius. https://youtu.be/hPfg20k5TE8?si=IQmmYP0HIbWPdzsi
When Ron responded "Frog?" I spit my by now luke-warm coffee all over my laptop. Best puzzle ever!

Ant eggs! When I got it from the crosses I assumed it was not really ant eggs. Like ants on a log, which are really raisins, but no! They really eat ( and farm) ant eggs.  I‚Äôm not sure I would be brave enough to try them, but how interesting world cuisine is.

I was cruzin' along quite nicely filling in the 3s and 4s with the usual fill then NO, NO, NO, etc. Took a peek at Sam's column. Aha!
Big payoff was 4A right at the end. Very fitting for an mid-October puzzle...got it in under the wire.
Possible 35A: NYT Associate puzzle editor's x-word ranking??

Took me way too long to get NERFED considering my older son‚Äôs current obsession with Nerf guns. I thought about it but kept expecting the Thai food clue to end in ng instead of gg and for whatever reason, eng seemed less likely to be correct than ang.  

Overall fun puzzle! I have enjoyed that the early week puzzles the last few days seem to be putting up a bit more resistance than usual.
what otherwise would have been a fun-themed wednesday was tarnished with some of the most creative naticks in recent memory.

Not totally happy with WWIIVET but otherwise a puzzle with lots of fun stuff and not too much "crosswordese.

INRUN was new for me and ANTEGG - do they really? 

Hard for a Wednesday but I enjoyed every square of it. 

Nice work

Thanks
What a challenge and a joy - so many unique and challenging clues and answers! Thank you both.

‚ÄúOh, boy!‚Äù, I thought, in noticing a favorite celebrity and co-puzzlemaker. But then, I took a pleasant journey, digging into my limited knowledge of tools and nostalgia of my grad school days in the machine shop. What fun‚Ä¶thank you, Mr. Offerman and Ms. Iverson!

This was a pretty crunchy puzzle for me which ultimately I liked QUITEABIT. But a lot gave me pause for a Wednesday. Somehow in my extensive nursery rhyme exposure I never came across JIGGETYJIG or even the word JIGGETY by itself. I eat a lot of Thai food  but never saw an ANTEGG on the menu. Never heard of  ALTTEXT and initially had trouble parsing PRO as a noun (PROs and cons I get it now). On the other hand I knew LORDJIM because I still remember it was the only assigned reading in high school I literally fell asleep reading. As for David SEDARIS that might have taken me a bit to pull out of my head were it not for the amazing coincidence that I had just seen his sister Amy starring in the latest ‚ÄúElsbeth‚Äù episode only minutes before. Loved BOSSLEVEL and always loved he gamer slang of NERFing for tweaking role-playing classes that have gotten too powerful. So overall a fun, educational puzzle.

Two thumbs up. Clever theme and an enjoyable workout. Was almost done when the theme finally dawned on me and that's always a nice touch. And... ...a bit surprised that no one else has noted the previous quite similar puzzle. A Monday from January 28, 2013 by Jamie Hutchison and Victor Fleming. The 'reveal' in that one was: WHATATOOL And.... MODELPLANE was also one of theme answers in that one. Some others: FUELLEVEL MIKEHAMMER FIREDRILL Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/28/2013&g=35&d=A ....

I can't ever remember throwing in the towel on a Wednesday, but there were enough obscure (to me) answers--"inrun," "eames," "brb," and even "antegg" (I suck at food questions)--that I had to hit Reveal and not feel too bad about it.

It‚Äôs very cool to see the NYT getting celebrity input for its puzzles, so I don‚Äôt want to pooh pooh this one too much, but it would be nice for Wednesday editions to be Wednesday-level difficulty for folks born after 1960. None of the following answers have been in common usage after the 1970s or so:
- JIGGETY
- GOB
- TURTLE
- POKEY
- GAS
- ETON
- EAMES
- REO
- ELIHU ROOT
- LORD JIM

Longest Wednesday solve for me in ages, and the most I've struggled on any day for many months. ELIHU and ANTEGG were real problems for me, as I was happy with MOB for 30A, never got comfortable with the answer for 24A though I had it correct, and kept going between SWORD and SCALE for 4A which is fairly amusing. I like the idea of the theme, but the prefix words kind of threw me for a loop, particularly 24A and 36A, leaving me without confidence that I knew what was going on. All that said, it is fun to imagine Nick working on this, and the tool theme is a great nod to him!

It's like my birthday came early! A puzzle from Nick Offerman and Christina Iverson!

I loved it. Favorite entries include AEGIS, POKEY, and JIGGETY JIG. I actually heard someone use the word POKEY in conversation recently, and it made my day.
Not difficult, but just not a satisfying solve for me.

I love Nick Offerman. But I like him a little less now.

But I‚Äôm not complaining.

Following up on yesterday‚Äôs soccer/futbol/football/fussball and Rx zealots, my imagination places me in a doctor‚Äôs office/surgery.         
  The doctor is treating the patient with a serious injury from a recent match on the field. You see, the player was a victim of a slide tackle, and is very upset that the referee produced no card. The doctor reminds the athlete ‚ÄúThat was a penalty and didn‚Äôt require a card.‚Äù A much heated discussion ensues.
  The doctor finally concedes and proceeds to write out a Rx for pain medication. When asked ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs this?‚Äù The doctor replies ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a scrip for some pain meds.‚Äù Player: ‚ÄúA what? You mean script!‚Äù Doc: ‚ÄúNo, a scrip. Player: Everyone knows it‚Äôs a script!‚Äù Doc: ‚ÄúRead the script, it‚Äôs a scrip!‚Äù

Apologies, there was no way to end that one, much like yesterday‚Äôs lunchtime learning session. I mean no harm. Carry on.
Alas, Elihu, I knew him not.

I‚Äôm a big Nick Offerman fan, but I‚Äôm an even bigger David Sedaris fan! I certainly hope that it was Nick who decided to incorporate Mr Sedaris in this puzzle. 
I recalled that the unlikely duo collaborated on the audiobook version of Lincoln in the Bardo. 
And David Sedaris has mentioned in several of his essays his love of crossword puzzles.

Probably the toughest Wednesday I‚Äôve done and it shouldn‚Äôt have been. So much in my wheelhouse as a woodworker and a man with a truck equipped with ONSTAR, yet so many little trip wires to step over. 
I‚Äôm a great admirer of Nick Offerman for his humor, intellect and support of the craft. I didn‚Äôt notice who constructed this but thoroughly enjoyed his note. Now I have another reason to cherish his good example. 
Thank you Christina and Nick.
I know about and enjoy Christina‚Äôs work, knew nothing of Nick ‚Äî but that‚Äôs nothing to do with the puzzle, which wasn‚Äôt much fun for me. Glad most others got a kick out of it, though.

The theme was inane and its answers were largely unsolvable on their own merit (heck, even with the crossing clues, how was one meant to decipher some of those). And before you comment, dear readers ‚Äî hi, yes, I‚Äôm sure you had no problem. Cookie for you. It‚Äôs still bad. :)

I say this not because of the theme (note to those who object to "jiggity jig":  this can't be the first time you had to solve a theme word with its crossers--get over it), which I found interesting and typical of Wednesday wordplay.  No, it was the overabundance of obscure trivia, and, as you will see as follows, I really got cheesed at the un-level and wildly misleading clue for "boss 'level'."  A carpenter's level is not an "implement for ensuring stability" (I was thinking a brace or a bracket or some other device that secures an object); it is an implement for determining whether a surface of an object is parallel or perpendicular to the earth (as represented by the force of gravity).  Such a determination MAY lead to a conclusion about the stability of some object, but whether that surface is level or plumb does not necessarily lead to any conclusion of (let alone the ensuring of) such object's stability (e.g., I'm not seeking to to ensure the stability of a picture frame hung on my wall, I'm determining whether my wife will approve of the installation job I did).

@Sam Lyons and wggwg , for academic interest: a digraph is two graphemes, which is only important when (as you pointed out) the relationship between letters and graphemes is unusual, or in flux, or both.

This doesn't invalidate anyone's arguments that the clue is correct. It's correct because "head" is intentionally ambiguous and could refer to one (or more) letters, graphemes, syllables, phonemes, ... .

"letter" arises from Sam, who in fact took Patrick's position that ll was still a single letter: 

"the ‚Äúhead,‚Äù i.e., first letter, [...] is a pair of ELS."

For more academic interest, taking a computer rather than linguistic approach: Unicode sometimes has codepoints for ligatures (e.g. IJ ), for compatibility reasons. But to my knowledge there is not one for LL. And even if there were, in "NFKD"* ("Decomposed" Normal Form) that hypothetical compatibility codepoint would decompose into 2 codepoints, which you would describe as ELS.

* For the Unicode pedants: but not in NFD, I checked
